responses.content:
Explanation: The original statement "The room must have been cleaned daily and it must have had fresh towels" contains two parts connected by the conjunction "and":
1. The room must have been cleaned daily
2. It must have had fresh towels

The proposed inference "The room must have been cleaned daily and had fresh towels" also contains two parts connected by "and":
1. The room must have been cleaned daily
2. [The room] had fresh towels

The first part of the inference is identical to the first part of the original statement. However, the second part of the inference drops the modal verb "must" and changes the verb form from "have had" to "had".

Dropping the "must" changes the certainty of the statement. In the original, it is necessary that the room had fresh towels. In the inference, it is merely stated that the room had fresh towels, without the certainty implied by "must".

Therefore, the inference is not entirely equivalent to the original statement, as it changes the modality of the second part.
